entry.title: what is the difference between science and religion?
entry.content:
Both science and religion are stories (memes) useful in explaining reality. There are distinct survival advantages to having a story -- it allows for prediction of cause and effect.

The difference from religion is that science makes physically quantifiable measurements to form the story. As a result, there is one coherent story. Though partial (an incomplete set of knowledge), there is a clear method for adding to the knowledge.

entry.title: open and closed systems of thinking
entry.content:
definition: an "open system of knowledge" is set of knowledge in which there exist questions which are quantifiably answerable but which have not yet been. There are known unknowns.
claim: science is an open system of knowledge. Whether due to lack of funding or lack of capable scientists, not all questions are answered. This may result in feelings of powerlessness.

definition: a "closed system of knowledge" is a set of knowledge in which all questions are answerable. 
claim: religion is a closed system of knowledge. All questions can be answered with generic answers such as "it is the will of God" or "it is part of God's plan." [These make no quantifiably testable predictions.] The result of the ability to answer all questions is a feeling of comfort -- someone is in charge of the seemingly crazy events. However, there can be a corresponding decrease in curiosity in seeking knowledge. Any action can be justified using the above generic answers. The ability to question the validity of these answers is also closed.

entry.title: where I am now
entry.content:
I occasionally run across atheists debating religious people. I feel sorry for the atheists, since they are invariably wasting their time. If religious people were logical, a debate might be meaningful. Often the atheist feels they have logic on their side, so they must be able to convince the religious person.

The religious person built their perspective on faith -- making decisions without evidence or even in spite of conflicting evidence. The religious perspective is not logical, thus logical arguments don't result in agreement with the atheist.

The root of lack of progress in any conversation can be traced to a problem with definitions. Either two parties don't agree on a definition, or there isn't a definition for the term. In either case, stop any talk until this lack of definitions or disagreement on definitions is resolved.  A person new to ignosticism may have difficulty with implementing this to sufficient detail.

When I say the word "capacitor," I am referring to a physical device with measurable properties. In this case a capacitor stores energy in an electric field (which can be physically quantified). A chicken (also physically measurable)  is very difficult to confuse with a capacitor. We use words to describe physical objects we are thinking about. How can we use words for more (apparently) abstract concepts like "freedom" and "happy"?

It turns out "happiness" can be measured by a functional MRIs, as can most feelings (depression, anger). On the other hand, the words like "freedom" are subjective because they lack any physical object or commonly-agreed upon measurement to make. What we can talk about objectively are the physical actions individuals take under the heading of freedom.

Summary:
If a person cannot define the terms they are using in a physically-quantifiably meaningful way, then any argument made using those terms is unmeasurable. If a statement is not measurable, then there is no way to test its validity.

entry.title: logically dealing with illogic
entry.content:
claim: Religion is illogical; science is logical.
Question: Can a logical thought system (science) be used to describe the illogic of religion? 
Answer: Yes.

A test of illogical systems of thought is their multiplicity. Any illogical system is equally useless.  [Some have more attractive memetic qualities.] Hindus and Christians and Buddhists have divergent views on cause and effect. [Again, commonality arises due to memetic survival.]

In contrast, there is one scientific method. Many disciplines exist (geology, physics, chemistry) but they apply the same method.
